channel.title: health on Newsround
channel.description: Recent content in health on Newsround

item.title: DOH reports travel-related Zika, dengue cases on Oahu - Honolulu Star-Advertiser
item.description: The Hawaii Department of Health said a travel-related Zika virus case has been confirmed on Oahu.

item.title: The Best Medicine For Joint Pain Isn't What You Think, Says Expert - ScienceAlert
item.description: Stiff knees, aching hips, and the slow grind of chronic joint pain are often accepted as an unavoidable part of getting older.

item.title: Deadly bacterial outbreak discovered at Berkeley homeless encampment - KTVU
2-year-old with ‘beautiful smile’ identified as first child flu death this season in N.J. - NJ.com
item.description: The child was not vaccinated for the flu, his family said.

item.title: Trini couple return home to focus on stigma of obesity - Trinidad and Tobago Newsday
item.description: A PAIR of Trini-born US board-certified doctors has returned to the twin islands to set up a practice which focuses on obesity and metabolic health.

item.title: 'Strange Trail' In Snow Leads Couple To A Tiny Animal Struggling To Survive - The Dodo
item.description: They found him just in time.

item.title: Neuroscientists Decipher Procrastination: A Brain Mechanism Explains Why People Leave Certain Tasks for Later - WIRED
item.description: New research has discovered that a neural circuit may explain procrastination. Scientists were able to disrupt this connection using a drug.

item.title: The 9 Best High-Protein Yogurts, According to a Dietitian - TODAY.com
item.description: Yogurt is a flavorful food celebrated for its protein content, but some have more of it than others. A registered dietitian ranks the best high-protein yogurts.

item.title: Veteran Firefighter Denied Insurance Coverage for Stage 4 Lung Cancer Treatment: ‘I Am Forced to Stand Here and Beg’ - Yahoo News UK
item.description: “An insurance company decided that profits matter more than the life of a man who spent his career protecting this city,” said Ken Jones’ daughter

item.title: Patches of low vaccination in the US are becoming bigger, riskier holes - CNN
item.description: Opting out of childhood vaccines is becoming more common across most of the United States, leaving larger shares of the population vulnerable to preventable diseases like measles, which is continuing its record-breaking spread across the country.

item.title: Disease tolerance and infection pathogenesis age-related tradeoffs in mice - Nature
item.description: Disease course and pathology an infection may cause can change owing to the structural and functional physiological changes that accumulate with age, but therapy can be tailored accordingly; disease tolerance genes show antagonistic pleiotropy.

item.title: A foundation model for continuous glucose monitoring data - Nature
item.description: GluFormer, a generative foundation model, uses continuous glucose monitoring data to accurately forecast glycaemia-related health responses, particularly for long-term outcomes.

item.title: What's behind this country's dramatic drop in the number of new orphans? - NPR
item.description: A new study offers good news from Uganda — although the cuts in U.S. aid cast a shadow over the reduction in deaths of parents from HIV/AIDS.

item.title: Scientists finally uncover why statins cause muscle pain - ScienceDaily
item.description: A new discovery may explain why so many people abandon cholesterol-lowering statins because of muscle pain and weakness. Researchers found that certain statins can latch onto a key muscle protein and trigger a tiny but harmful calcium leak inside muscle cells…

item.title: 18 Myths About Your Health You Can Ignore in 2026 - CNET
item.description: When science disagrees with conventional wisdom.

item.title: Cancer might evade immune defences by stealing mitochondria - Nature
item.description: Hijacking the energy-producing organelles from immune cells seems to help tumours in mice to infiltrate lymph nodes.

item.title: Massive brain study reveals why memory loss can suddenly speed up with age - ScienceDaily
item.description: A massive international brain study has revealed that memory decline with age isn’t driven by a single brain region or gene, but by widespread structural changes across the brain that build up over time. Analyzing thousands of MRI scans and memory tests from …
